Mr. Robb, with a few prefatory remarks, offered a resolution authorizing the Chair h
appoint three committees,viz.: one on Routes; one on Ways and Means, and one*™
Resolutions. The resolution was adopted without dissent, the Chair to announce ji.
committees at tbe next meeting.
A gentleman, whose name we did not hear, asked if all tbe routes which were entiiU
to the friendly regard of the various delegations present, were to be referred lo the Com.
mittee on Routes.
Mr. Robb explained that tbe object of his resolution, and the appointment of the com-
mittees referred to, was to prevent that dissipation of influence and power, which vooU
inevitably result from the open debate of every scheme that might be brought before tie
Convention, They met not for an idle purpose; not for the mere "expression of
opinion, but to accomplish results, and those results should be accomplished. The object
was to devise practicable projects ; lo establish a grand system of railroads, which would
make New-Orleans and the Southwest what they ought to he, and to devise thewaji
and means by which this great end might be attained. In the course of his remarks,be
expressed his high gratification at the large and influential assemblage he saw before bin,
and from the spirit which animated it, argued undoubted and early success.
Mr. Hampson, of Louisiana, offered a resolution that in voting, each state should hare
but one vote, and the resolution was referred to the Committee on Resolutions,
Tuesday, January 6,1852.
MORNING SESSION.
The Convention metal half past 11 o'clock, a. m.
The minutes of yesterday's sittings were read and approved.
